entry.title: December '25 news
entry.summary: In December we shipped a set of updates aimed at better usability, clearer admin controls, more transparency, and core stability improvements. Most changes came in the final week of the year, and all are available in the GitHub Releases history.
entry.content:
In December we shipped a set of updates aimed at better usability, clearer admin controls, more transparency, and core stability improvements. Most changes came in the final week of the year, and all are available in the GitHub Releases history.

üóì Better Booking Experience

  • Calendar view added to ‚ÄúMy Bookings‚Äù: Users now see their bookings in a calendar layout, making it easier to scan multiple dates and times.
  • Improved date/time picker: The date/time selector across the UI now uses a refined Flatpickr implementation for smoother interactions.
  • Current filter shown in Admin Booking UI: Admins get clearer context about what bookings are being displayed rather than guessing which filters are applied.

üìß Email Transparency and Confirmations

  • Email log introduced: Admins can now track sent emails, improving visibility into system communications.
  • Confirmation mail for organization deletion: When an org is deleted, a confirmation email will be sent ‚Äî adding a safety feedback loop.
  • Improved email recipient names: Emails now show clearer recipient details for better context.
  • Mail log callback fix for ACS: Resolved an issue where the mail log wasn‚Äôt invoked when using Azure Communication Services (ACS).

‚öôÔ∏è Booking Rules & Admin Controls

  • Recurring bookings toggle: Admins can enable or disable recurring bookings via configuration, reducing unwanted repeats.
  • Optional booking approver notifications: You decide whether approvers get notified about new pending bookings.

üß† Clarity and Feedback in the UI

  • Error improvement when booking in the past: A clearer error code is provided if someone tries to create a booking in the past.
  • Show org language & primary contact on settings page: Admin settings now surface organization language and main contact info.

üîß Bug Fixes and Dependency Hygiene

December releases also included:

  • Translation fixes (e.g., German strings).
  • Dependency bumps across UI and backend modules to keep libraries up to date.
  • Fix for panic when user/org deleted but token still valid.

These don‚Äôt change workflows directly but reduce friction and unexpected errors.

What This Means for You

  • You get more clarity on your bookings and communications.
  • Admins now have tighter control over rules like recurring booking and approver notifications.
  • UX feels more polished, with fewer rough edges when selecting dates or managing filters.

üìã More details

As always, you can find detailed information about all recent releases and technical changes on our GitHub releases page.

entry.title: inki, the wireless e-paper display for Seatsurfing
entry.summary: We‚Äôre thrilled to shine a spotlight on an open-source project closely integrated with Seatsurfing ‚Äî inki, developed by the maintainer c0de111. inki is a Community-developed software which brings live seating and room-booking data from Seatsurfing directly to your office walls ‚Äî and it does so with elegance, sustainability, and very little maintenance.
entry.content:
We‚Äôre thrilled to shine a spotlight on an open-source project closely integrated with Seatsurfing ‚Äî inki, developed by the maintainer c0de111. inki is a Community-developed software which brings live seating and room-booking data from Seatsurfing directly to your office walls ‚Äî and it does so with elegance, sustainability, and very little maintenance.

What is inki?‚Äã

inki is a software for bare-metal systems like the Raspberry Pi Pico W, designed specifically for low-power operation. It wakes up periodically via a real-time clock (RTC), fetches data via Wi-Fi (e.g., from Seatsurfing‚Äôs REST API), displays that information on an e-paper screen, and then powers itself down ‚Äî all autonomously.

The project supports two e-paper sizes ‚Äî 4.2" and 7.5", allowing you to choose the form factor that best fits your space. Because e-paper retains its content even when unpowered, the display remains readable without consuming power.

Why it‚Äôs a perfect fit for Seatsurfing‚Äã

  • Live desk & room status: Once configured, inki queries your Seatsurfing server to pull the current booking status (who is sitting where, which rooms are occupied, etc.) and displays it cleanly on the screen.
  • Browser-based setup: You configure inki via its own Wi-Fi access point. Point your browser to the setup page, enter your Seatsurfing API credentials (such as service account, space IDs), and you‚Äôre ready to go ‚Äî no cables, no USB programmers.
  • Logo & branding: You can even upload a custom logo or pictogram to be shown on the e-paper ‚Äì making the display match your company‚Äôs visual identity.
  • Low maintenance: Thanks to the RTC-based power control, the device can run for thousands of update cycles on simple AA or AAA batteries.

Key technical features‚Äã

  • Ultra-low power: Uses a DS3231 RTC and a MOSFET circuit so that the Pico W is completely unpowered between wake-ups, drawing only micro-amperes.
  • Wireless updates: Firmware updates are done over the air. Just connect to the inki Wi-Fi, upload the new firmware via browser, and reboot.
  • Multiple pages: inki supports up to 8 configurable ‚Äúpages‚Äù that users can cycle through using onboard buttons ‚Äî e.g., room occupancy, ‚ÄúDo Not Disturb,‚Äù device info, and more.
  • Hardware & open source: The project provides full hardware design files (PCB, 3D-printed enclosure), firmware (C code), and documentation under open-source licenses.

Real-world use cases‚Äã

  • Room signage: Mount inki outside meeting rooms to display real-time status (free, occupied, meeting name) pulled from Seatsurfing.
  • Desk sharing boards: Use in open offices to give a live visual overview of who is sitting where.
  • Beyond booking: Thanks to its modular firmware, inki can be repurposed for other data-display roles ‚Äî for example, visualizing live sensor data from home automation systems (e.g., Homematic/CCU Historian).

Why we love it‚Äã

inki embodies the principles of simplicity, efficiency, and practicality ‚Äî qualities that resonate deeply with Seatsurfing‚Äôs mission. By combining ultra-low power hardware with a smart software design, it creates a seamless, tangible way to connect digital booking data with physical space. inki achieves this by using the documented REST APIs provided by Seatsurfing's open source project. It‚Äôs exactly the kind of community-driven innovation we hoped for when we open-sourced Seatsurfing.

Getting started‚Äã

If you‚Äôre interested in using inki with your Seatsurfing instance:

  1. Visit the inki project website: c0de111.github.io/inki
  2. Download the inki_seatsurfing.uf2 firmware from the GitHub repository.
  3. Flash it onto a Pico W, set it up via its Wi-Fi interface, configure Seatsurfing API credentials, and select your space ID.
  4. Insert batteries, mount the device, and enjoy a live status display that literally runs for years.

A big thanks to the creator‚Äã

We‚Äôd like to express our deep gratitude to c0de111 for building this neat integration. Projects like inki make the Seatsurfing ecosystem richer ‚Äî they bridge the gap between the digital booking world and physical reality, in a way that feels intuitive and elegant. ‚ù§Ô∏è

entry.title: Seatsurfing 1.32 released
entry.summary: We're happy to announce the availability of Seatsurfing version 1.32. Everything in this new version is about groups: You can now organize your users in groups. These groups can be used as approvers for your spaces, i.e. a space admin in a space's approver group must approve a user's booking request before it becomes definite. Furthermore, you can use groups to restrict users who can book specific spaces, i.e. only users in an allowed group are permitted to place a booking.

entry.title: Seatsurfing 1.10 replaces native apps with web app
entry.summary: As of July 30, 2022, the Seatsurfing mobile apps for iOS and Android will be discontinued. We decided to focus on one state-of-the-art web booking interface, which is the existing, yet improved Web Booking UI. In order to optimize the user experience of the Web Booking UI when using mobile devices (such as phones and tablets), we've turned it into a Progressive Web App (PWA). This means, you can "install" the web app to your device's home screen and benefit from enhanced caching mechanisms.
entry.content:
As of July 30, 2022, the Seatsurfing mobile apps for iOS and Android will be discontinued. We decided to focus on one state-of-the-art web booking interface, which is the existing, yet improved Web Booking UI. In order to optimize the user experience of the Web Booking UI when using mobile devices (such as phones and tablets), we've turned it into a Progressive Web App (PWA). This means, you can "install" the web app to your device's home screen and benefit from enhanced caching mechanisms.

As usual, you can find the source code of version 1.10 on GitHub and pre-built Docker images on Docker Hub.
